title: Airbnb analysts largely maintain their price targets even after soft guidance
text:
It recorded 99.7 million nights and experiences bookings in the July to September period, just behind analysts' estimates of 100.68 million. The average daily rate was $156, up 5% year over year and higher than the $153.20 analysts expected.

Yet, the San-Francisco-based company said it expects its bookings for the fourth quarter to "moderate slightly" due to pressure from currency headwinds and business mix.

"We continue to thrive despite macroeconomic uncertainties," chief executive Brian Chesky said during the investor presentation on Tuesday.

Shares in Airbnb ABNB were down 7% in pre-market trading at $101.77 on Wednesday.

Airbnb stock drops despite 'biggest and most profitable quarter ever'

Evercore ISI highlighted that the company has a "reasonable track record of somewhat conservative guidance."

The team, led by Mark Mahaney said Airbnb's cautions that average daily rates will face pressure from FX and business mix caused them to change its 2023 ADR outlook from down 2% to down 7%.

The analysts maintained their outperform rating and $150 per share price target, but questioned executives' optimism of "promising trends in cross-border travel".

"How can leisure travel demand possibly hold up in THIS macro environment? We assume the demand will weaken sooner or later," they said in a note.

JP Morgan analysts led by Doug Anmuth kept their neutral rating in Airbnb and price target of $105 per share due to not seeing any "negative impact on demand from macro headwinds that are beginning to weigh on the consumer as the soft 4Q guide is driven by FX & shift in business mix."

"Overall, we believe ABNB continues to execute well across top & bottom lines & product innovation remains strong. While ABNB is not seeing signs of slowing demand or supply, we believe investor concern around the potential for macro headwinds to weigh on travel will continue to drive share performance," the team said.

RBC analysts also said the profitability was "impressive" but the Q4 guidance showed "disappointing deceleration pointing to meaningful downside to Street '23 estimates."

The team reiterated its sector perform rating and kept its $110 price target.

Airbnb analysts largely maintain their price targets even after soft guidance
